title: Before 1 April 2019, how many countries will formally progress in the NATO accession process?
preds:
Currently, four partner countries have declared their aspirations to NATO membership: Bosnia and Herzegovina, Georgia, the Republic of North Macedonia and Ukraine.
Under Zelensky, Razumkov said, Ukraine would continue aspiring to join the European Union and NATO, but it would hold a referendum on the issues only when the chance of doing so was realistic.
There are currently 4 countries looking to join NATO; Bosnia and Herzegovina, Georgia, the Republic of North Macedonia, and Ukraine. 
While Ukraine is in the midst of an election, both the incumbent Poroshenko and his leading opponent Zalensky have expressed a desire to join NATO, although no specific timeline has been given, and Zalensky, who recently won a run-off election, has stated that he would wait until the time is right. So while an actual timeline is up in the air, it seems likely that whomever wins the presidential election will seek to hold ascension talks with NATO as well as MAP, due to Poroshenko meeting with NATO this past December, in which NATO reaffirmed support for Ukraine against Russian aggression. 
NATO announced at a meeting in December 2018 that it is prepared to accept the submission of an ANP by Bosnia and Herzegovina. While some members of the presidency welcomed this new development and expressed hope that state institutions would begin developing an ANP, the leader of the Serb nationaalists in the presidency has repeatedly been against NATO membership. It’s clear that any closer movement by Bosnia and Herzegovina will be contingent on dealing with conflict amongst its different ethnic groups.
Due to the ongoing situation in Ukraine, I find it doubtful that Georgia will make any serious moves to join NATO before April 1st. Allowing Georgia to go further along in the membership process would place pressure on Russia that could impede negotiations over the Ukrainian conflict and impede NATO operations in other areas, so both Georgia and NATO are better served maintaining their current cooperative relationship. 
The Republic of North Macedonia formally signed a letter for ascension in February, and will likely be a full member by the end of the year.
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2019/03/zelensky-face-poroshenko-ukraine-run-exit-poll-190331171422240.html
https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/topics_49212.htm
https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-polytics/2671315-poroshenko-we-will-either-reaffirm-course-for-eu-nato-or-return-to-2013.html
https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/topics_49127.htm
https://www.rferl.org/a/nato-gives-bosnia-green-light-to-move-toward-membership/29639709.html
https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/06/world/europe/north-macedonia-nato-russia.html
Updating from 0/98/2/0/0. Time's up, pretty much.

Expansion slow, but recognition by NATO is active for at least one country at a time. Most recently North Macedonia signed accession protocol in February and is awaiting ratification, but the most recent country to be formally added was Montenegro

Of the 4 countries in the pipeline, only North Macedonia has moved forward. Hence, it will be the only country to join. However, April 2019 will be too early to join as all 29 members have to ratify the ascension protocol.

Currently, there are 4 NATO aspirant countries. In the past, seventeen countries have joined NATO. With my own research, many, but not all, countries move forward in the process within the year they applied (the Visegrád Group ascending after 10 months, the Vilnius Group ascending after about 8 months, Montenegro after 13 months).  Currently, North Macedonia has the highest chance of ascending seeing as their October 2018 proposal was accepted in 2019. It is very likely. Bosnia and Herzegovina submitted a proposal on December 5th, 2018 and while an April 1st turn around would not be unheard of, the swiftness may be unlikely considering Serbia's current opposition of the country and their own debates on joining NATO. Therefore, their ascension is unlikely but possible. Georgia is very unlikely since NATO members were reluctant to accept their 2014 Membership Action Plan, and a 5-year delay in acceptance has not been seen in any NATO member post-USSR.  Ukraine was recognized as an aspirant country in March 2018 and they have made joining NATO and the EU a primary foreign policy goal as of September. However, Ukraine has not acted on that mission as of yet and assuming they do tomorrow, it would be a NATO first to respond that quickly before April 1st. Therefore, North Macedonia seems to be the only accending country.

Reviewing the two prior rounds of NATO enlargement, 2004 and 2009, we can identify two important trends in the process for NATO integration. First, the process almost always takes more than 5 years, due to the need for ratification by every existing member and the need for the country wishing to access to NATO to conform its armed forces to a certain degree of interoperability before being allowed to move forward. Secondly, As we can see from the most recent two NATO members, Albania and Croatia, even when all requirements are met formal accession does not usually occur by independent nations, as NATO seems to have a tendency to "group" countries together and have multiple formally become members at the same time. Given this, I would rate the likelihood of the only reasonable candidate for NATO accession, N. Macedonia, as unlikely before the date required, as such an event would constitute a shift in procedure for NATO which generally is a very procedural institution.  http://www.summitbucharest.ro/en/doc_202.html
https://www.nato.int/cps/ie/natohq/topics_49212.htm#

Updating from 0/94/6/0/0. I discard Serbia because apparently its people and govt oppose joining NATO [1]. I also update Georgia + Ukraine to only a ~1.3% chance in the remaining 3 weeks, following the same calculations as in my original forecast [2]. Call it 2% to be conservative. [1] https://balkaninsight.com/2019/03/06/hemmed-in-by-nato-serbias-neutrality-to-be-tested/?nocache=1
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/825705

My prediction is pretty consistent with the "crowd forecast," only a bit more skeptical of the time frame. Many individuals who have posted on this question give strong indications that Macedonia will formally become a part of NATO, and I agree, I just don't have full confidence that it will happen within the month.
The main obstacle for Macedonia's accession was due to a dispute with Greece based on the country's name. After a formal name change to Northern Macedonia has been approved by Greece, Northern Macedonia is acting as a NATO invitee. 
Reuters projects that Macedonia will join NATO mid-2020, there is also concern of Russia's  “malign influence” in Macedonia which could undermine government efforts to join the EU and NATO.
https://www.voanews.com/a/greece-to-ratify-macedonia-s-nato-membership-this-week/4773298.html
https://www.wsj.com/articles/greece-approves-macedonias-nato-membership-bid-11549657953
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-macedonia-nato-usa/u-s-sees-macedonia-in-nato-in-mid-2020-after-name-change-deal-idUSKBN1O31ZU
Northern Macedonia have ascended, but, so close to the question's deadline, it is highly unlikely that any others will complete the process on time.
Excellent news and analysis from @pietrokc on 8 Feb 2019.
Updating for the passage of time.

Bosnia and Herzegovina, the republic of north Macedonia, Ukraine and Georgia are currently expressing a keen interest to join NATO and it is possible that there may be other countries that want to follow in their footsteps.

(Newly Northern) Macedonia's full accession puts the count at a minimum of 1 with 40 days remaining in the Q.  The likelihood of any change occurring with regard to other likely joiners (i.e. Bosnia and Herzegovina, Georgia, Ukraine, Cyprus and Serbia) is quite low over the near term, due to the short time period in question  and Western hesitance to exacerbate tensions with Russia so soon after Macedonia's accession (especially given the present tension in Ukraine). *Editing dates. Honestly, I forgot March existed.

Revising from 0/88/12/0/0. Seven weeks to go. My understanding was that (Northern) Macedonia had already done a step last year that qualified it. (Remember, Q started on 18 Apr 2018.) But now it seems to have done another (full acession?), which removes all doubt. So the question becomes, will another country do another step? As I see it there are 3 groups of European/European-adjacent countries: (1) Those currently in the NATO process: Bosnia and Herzegovina, Georgia, Ukraine.
(2) Those that already explicitly decided not to join, e.g. by having a policy of neutrality and/or being in the Non-Aligned Movement [1]: Austria, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Finland, Ireland, Malta, Sweden, Switzerland.
(3) Those not in the process, but which haven't opted out either: Armenia, Cyprus, Moldova, Serbia. You could include Kosovo here, but ~4 NATO members don't even recognize Kosovo as a sovereign state so I don't think it will engage with NATO until that's resolved. I was trying to dragonfly-eye this Q by considering other countries (e.g. Mexico, North Africa) but it turns out the rules of NATO specify only European countries may join [2]. Those rules could be changed, but not in 7 weeks. Apparently BH's process is stalled due to "immovable defense property" [3]. The page saying this, besides being official NATO material, seems to be kept up-to-date: it contains developments from 6 Feb 2019 (48h ago). So I discard BH. What to expect from Georgia and Ukraine? Inside-view info seems noisy and contradictory, so let's just take an average. NATO has gone from 12 to 30 countries in 70 years. That means 18 countries completed 8 steps each in 70 years, or ~0.114 steps per country per year. That means 2 countries should do ~0.031 steps every 7 weeks. Plugging that into a Poisson calculator [4] we get ~3% chance of another step by Georgia or Ukraine in the timeframe. What to expect from Armenia, Cyprus, Moldova, Serbia? I discard Armenia and Moldova because they have signed up for other kinds of partnership with NATO besides membership, kinds like non-member states have (e.g. the Partnership for Peace, like Ireland); and because they are part of other organizations that include Russia. I further discard Cyprus because it is having trouble even joining the PfP, due to some conflict with Turkey. That leaves Serbia; if 18 countries joined in 70 years, that means ~0.0346 countries start the process every 7 weeks. Using the Poisson calculator again, we get a ~3% chance for Serbia to start the process. Since I rounded both Serbia and Georgia+Ukraine numbers down, let's make it 7% total chance that another country besides Macedonia completes a step. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement#Current_members
[2] https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/topics_49212.htm
[3] https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/topics_49212.htm
[4] https://stattrek.com/online-calculator/poisson.aspx
[5] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_NATO

I don't see the remaining three making any progress by 01 April. "Currently, four partner countries have declared their aspirations to NATO membership: Bosnia and Herzegovina, Georgia, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia¹ and Ukraine."[1] [1] https://www.nato.int/cps/ie/natohq/topics_49212.htm

From the Economist:
NATO signed a protocol to admit Macedonia as a future member. The country’s path to accession was cleared when it agreed to adopt a new name—Northern Macedonia—thus appeasing Greece, which has its own region called Macedonia. It will become NATO’s 30th member. The last country to join the military alliance was Montenegro in 2017.

Currently, there are 4 countries aiming for NATO membership: Georgia- Has been an aspirant country since 2011, but their progression has been slow, with nothing of note since December of 2017. Bosnia and Herzegovina- Began the process in 2008, but some domestic opposition and an unsolved NATO requirement regarding military property has hampered their effects. Ukraine- Ukraine has pushed hard to join NATO, but are still involved in conflict on their eastern front regarding territory claims. Since member states have to pledge to resolve disputes peacefully, Ukraine, too, seems unlikely. Macedonia- Macedonia holds the most promise. After finally resolving a dispute over their name with Greece, they will meet with NATO members on February 6. All signs point to Greece not blocking Macedonia moving forward. I'm putting 94% on Macedonia moving forward with 6% on no one moving forward. 5% is usually considered statistically significant, but I'm not ready to put that much faith in the deal.
With Greece withdrawing it's objection by way of Parliamentary measure. It becomes very likely that Macedonia will advance.
North Macedonia is well on its way. Don't think the US would want to expand NATO any further and alienate Russia in the process.

Hat tip to Hammer-Time for his excellent reference on this topic:
https://www.euractiv.com/section/enlargement/news/symbolically-greece-to-be-first-to-open-nato-doors-for-north-macedonia/
North Macedonia and Greece made huge strides in moving this forward this month.
Only uncertainty now is how fast NATO can move. Dateline 1-28-2019 https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-01-28/north-macedonia-dashes-toward-nato-entry-after-name-change-deal
Greek parliament approved “North Macedonia” which will join EU and NATO. I admit still question of timing.

Macedonia has Slovenia's full support for efforts for EU, NATO memberships: Slovenian minister Slovenia has already agreed on the NATO pre-accession protocol for Macedonia, which should be ratified by all NATO members. Sekerinska underlined that "it is necessary for Prespa Agreement to be fully ratified, so that all the members, including Slovenia, sign the Accession Protocol and we expect the Greek Parliament to fulfill its part of obligation this week."

The head of NATO’s intelligence and security division, Ambassador Arndt Freytag von Loringhoven, started three days of talks in Skopje on Monday (21 January 2019) focused on reforming the country’s defence and security institutions. https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/news_162536.htm
More Greek resistance than I thought.

Note the vote in Greece is set to happen this week. Sure the Greeks are protesting...too bad that wasn’t a profession. My wife joined a protest there a couple years ago - they were protesting communism, capitalism, fascism, and the EU. Couldn’t figure out what they were for - seemed to be against everything.
Regardless if vote happens this week, good chance Macedonia will act quickly.
https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-46938371

And it's unclear whether Sarajevo will accept NATO's invitation. "We made our decision: we are ready to receive their annual national program. But let them decide and we are ready if they are ready," NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg told reporters after the Brussels meeting.
Smart money laser focused on 1. Giving outlier 2 a chance..

Bosnia +
originally invited to join the MAP in April 2010 under the condition that no Annual National Programme would be launched until one of the conditions for the OHR closure – the transfer of control of immovable defence property to the central Bosnian authorities from the two regional political entities – ws fulfilled.[64] Condition waived in 2018.https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enlargement_of_NATO http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/nato-approves-membership-action-plan-with-bosnia-12-05-2018
Makedonia +
Georgia and Ukrain ??
 Invitees send letters of intent to NATO, along with timetables for completion of reforms ??

Note Greek election looming (Oct). Will Tsipras hold vote soon (likely but not certain) on Macedonia clearing way for NATO - already agreed to process. Argue accession criteria already covered given events of 2018
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accession_of_Macedonia_to_NATO
https://www.economist.com/node/21757492?frsc=dg%7Ce
Negotiations and the processes towards joining of the aspirant countries will take a long time - a minimum of 9-12 months.

Looks like Macedonia already happened in July or October 2018. How likely we'd get any others? Only 2 months left. Base rate: 19 countries have been added over 69 years. Assuming they each went through the 9 steps listed in Q description, that's 9*19/69 ~ 2.5 country-steps per year, or ~0.4 in 2 months. Plugging that into a Poisson distribution I get 33% of another one. However, there are simply fewer countries out of NATO now than there were before; eyeballing [2] there are at least 3x fewer countries. So taking a cube root, or dividing by 3, or dividing the Poisson rate by 3, I get kind of the same result: 12% chance of another one. [1] https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/topics_49212.htm
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Member_states_of_NATO#/media/File:Location_NATO_2017_blue.svg

Current candidates have been "in progress" a decade or more. With "North" Macedonia's naming issue resolved, it's basically a race against the clock as to whether it will progress prior to April. That said, I am confident it will make progress some time during 2019. I don't believe any of the other NATO candidates will move forward before April.

Looks as though the Greek vote on Macedonia's name change is the last hurdle before advancing, which should be completed well before the question's 1 April end date. It doesn't appear that the other three aspiring members have the political will to move forward during the given time frame. According to Sekerinska, the signing of NATO accession protocol will be drafted once Prespa Agreement on the name settlement is implemented and ratified by Macedonia and Greece."This timeframe is several weeks, expecting the NATO protocol to be drafted after the deal's ratification in the Greek parliament, followed by the protocol's endorsement by Greek lawmakers," Sekerinska explained, adding that Macedonia will achieve its strategic objective as of February. - http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2019-01/06/c_137722359.htm NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg said in October that Macedonia’s accession talks may be completed by the end of January. - https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-01-11/balkan-state-backs-name-change-in-step-toward-joining-nato-eu
Russia will resist all attempts to block Ukraine, Georgia and Macedonia from membership. If all goes well with the negotiations with Bosnia, it will be the next country to become a member in 2019.
Way to go Greece (confidence votes all the rage).

Moving my 1 country progressing down a bit in reaction to this ( https://twitter.com/EuropeElects/status/1084433577004154880 /https://www.cnbc.com/2019/01/13/greek-pm-alexis-tsipras-says-to-call-a-confidence-vote-in-parliament.html ) looks like Tsipras will just hold on

Macedonia has voted to change it's name, so it looks like they will progress before 1 April. This removed the last widely held objection in the Greek parliament. They should be voting in favour the agreement before the end of the month. It is unlikely any other NATO member will object.
It's unlikely any other potential member countries will ascend. https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-46846231

Macedonia has voted to change it's name, so it looks like they will progress before 1 April, other potential countries will not. The Greek parliament should be voting on the agreement before the end of the month. https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-46846231

higher tensions in the region mean it would be a terrible idea to bring another player into NATO right now.
With several countries leaning a little more toward nativism, I think NATO will be very careful about who they are letting join NATO.

Macedonia was invited to join at the July 2018 summit, advancing them one stage in the accession process. I really should have updated the question earlier. That said, no other country is in a position to advance in the time frame.

Macedonia gets high marks from the #DemoIndex, suggesting a clear path to joining NATO. Prianthi Roy
‏ @prianthiroy
1h1 hour ago In 2018 eastern Europe’s overall score in the #DemoIndex improved marginally, but the region still lags behind North America and Western Europe. Substantial improvements in Armenia, Estonia and Macedonia’s score more than offset the sharp drop in scores for Russia and Georgia.

The reason that I am changing my forecast is that I did not read the start date of the challenge.  Macedonia has progressed a stage since 1 April 2018. My excuse is that I did not start the forecasting until December 2018 and then only thinking of accession progress going forward from December.  Bad oversight.
I dont see another in addition to Macedonia

No additional countries will be added to NATO.  The situation with Russia is too intense at the moment.  An expansion of NATO will be seen by the Russians as Western aggression and NATO leaders have been behaving in a manner that, they believe, will prevent provoking Russia.  Also, the sense that America is declining as the "world police" and insinuations by the Trump administration as well as populist politicians in America, both on the left & right, would suggest to potential member states that the main benefit of NATO, which is American military protection, will not actually be fulfilled and only serve to make them a potential target for NATO's rivals.
Only one country will ask due to Russian aggression.

Raising my expectation that Macedonia will progress in the accession process, they are voting on the name change Jan 12th, and that seems to be the last major bar to joining (Greece wanted them to change their name) https://worldview.stratfor.com/situation-report/macedonia-parliament-vote-name-change-jan-12 Tsipras has said that he will secure a parliamentary majority for Prespa Agreement and the protocol for joining NATO and that looks to be early February ( https://europeanwesternbalkans.com/2019/01/04/process-constitutional-changes-macedonia-enter-final-phase-zaev-optimistic/ ) so it looks like they will be able to move forward in the process. Other potential NATO members don't seem likely to make any progression before April.

Given the recent friction regarding Turkey, an average continental mandate for membership would be low right now, leaving aside that Trump's election is some evidence that joining doesn't get a huge deal on defense spending.

Bosnia has moved forward - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accession_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina_to_NATO
Macedonia is moving forward - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accession_of_Macedonia_to_NATO
Could be 2 or 1 or 0.
Ukraine and Georgia have no chance.

Currently there are 4 countries that are interested in joining NATO: Georgia, Ukraine, Bosnia and Macedonia.  
Russia's presence in Georgia and Ukraine creates a complex political situation.  It is not clear how they can join NATO without creating unstable situation there.  There is zero chance that either country will advance in the progression in the time frame in this question.
Politics also plays in the Bosnia case.  The question of how to deal with the Serbian armament in Bosnia (the so-called immovable defense properties) is intractable, especially within the short time frame, and therefore, zero chance.
Name-change is the last hurdle for Macedonia to join NATO. With the name-change referendum (passed with over 90% of the votes, but invalid due to low turnout) out of the way, the parliament is working on the name-change by legislation.  There is a good chance that Macedonia will join NATO in a short time frame.

By adopting NATO's enlargement policy, it will move towards the Western Balkans or possibly the Scandinavian countries (the public and the government must be in agreement). As far as the accession of Ukraine and Georgia is concerned, due to frozen conflicts, it is expected that the involvement at the current level will be maintained.

It not to expect that NATO will push progress for Ukraine and Georgia as those are in active conflicts with Russia.
Also for the the other prospect I don´t expect any progress in short time.

The four countries aspiring to join NATO are: Bosnia-Herzegovina, Ukraine, Macedonia, and Georgia.  At the Western Balkans Summit in July 2018 there were talks about Macedonia's accession process. Macedonia’s accession talks are expected to finish by January and the accession protocol is also planned to be signed at that point. At this point, Macedonia and NATO also signed the plan for the accession process. Because of this, they are the country out of the four most likely to formally progress in the accession process. 
With the Russia-Ukraine conflict, Ukraine is unlikely to progress in the process before April 2019. Bosnia-Herzegovina is unlikely to progress as well because it has still not be able to fulfill the condition to launch an Annual National Programme under its MAP (which was in 2010-2011). Similarly, Georgia is not far enough in the process to be able to progress by April.  https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/topics_49212.htm
https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natolive/topics_37750.htm
https://www.euractiv.com/section/politics/news/macedonia-roadmap-to-nato-explained/
SECDEF and NATO WANT MACEDONIA NOW

In the current formal Accession process, Ukraine, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Macedonia are the countries most likely to formally progress. Ukraine has failed to join MAP due to their conflict with Russia, and they are not likely to end the conflict before April of 2019, so they are not likely to progress. Bosnia and Herzegovina have also hindered their progress due to a reform issue concerning immovable property that they have not yet resolved. Macedonia is likely to progress since they have started official accession talks and have participated in MAP since 1999. https://europeanwesternbalkans.com/2018/10/10/macedonia-launch-official-accession-talks-nato-next-week/
https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/topics_49212.htm
https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/nato-hopeful-macedonia-displays-military-alliance-59029861
https://www.brookings.edu/blog/order-from-chaos/2017/07/25/will-ukraine-join-nato-a-course-for-disappointment/
As per Shiva Diva, Macedonia has voted in name change.

Formal Accession Talks with Skopje begin at NATO Headquarters
https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/news_159541.htm NATO seems to beieve it will happen. Macedonia lawmakers green light process for name change
https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/macedonian-lawmakers-gear-up-for-vote-to-amend-constitution/2018/10/19/09dc9218-d37a-11e8-a4db-184311d27129_story.html?noredirect=on&utm_term=.ad584fded5fc
Macedonian parliament voted to proceed with name change.
Macedonia is one after name change. Maybe another one on top. Ukraine will have elections and might push for it and new IMF program might be part of electoral debate, but prob too soon.

Of the four countries currently listed by NATO as aspirational (Bosnia and Herzegovina, Georgia, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, and Ukraine), Macedonia is the furthest along, based on statements by NATO (https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/topics_49212.htm). However, the recent failure of the referendum on Macedonia's name change (https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/failed-macedonian-referendum-181001185416308.html) further confirms the already apparent difficulties in getting though even this first condition required to begin the formal accession process as laid out in July when the NATO Secretary General announced NATO's invitation to the government in Skopje to begin talks (https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/news_157315.htm). The referendum also showed significant popular support for NATO accession—and since the referendum was only advisory, not binding, there is still ample room for progress in the name-change debate. But, resolving this key dispute and formally amending Macedonia’s constitution to reflect the new name before April seems like a tall order.

Currently, four partner countries have declared their aspirations to NATO membership: Bosnia and Herzegovina, Georgia, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and Ukraine, but the country that has the highest likelihood of gaining membership by April 2019 is Macedonia. Macedonia's greatest challenge that could possibly hinder this accession is the conflict over the name of the country. NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg called on Macedonians at the end of September to vote in a referendum to embrace a deal on its name with neighboring Greece and join the defense alliance. However, Macedonians have rejected an attempt to change the name of their nation to North Macedonia, which could mean their country will remain outside the regional power blocs of NATO and the European Union. https://www.nato.int/cps/ie/natohq/topics_49212.htm
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-nato-macedonia/we-are-ready-to-welcome-you-natos-stoltenberg-tells-macedonia-idUSKCN1LM2MQ
https://www.businessinsider.com/macedonia-refuses-name-change-means-its-stuck-outside-eu-and-nato-2018-10
Shifting toward zero from two based on the issues with the recent Macedonian referendum. I am thinking Sweden advances based on its worries about Russia.

I believe there is a 99% chance that one country will formally progress in the NATO accession process. The country that will formally proceed is Macedonia. As we have seen in headlines and current news, Macedonia is well on its way to becoming a NATO member.  Beginning in July, during the Summit in Brussels, NATO leaders decided to invite Macedonia to begin accession talks. Since then, there has only been positive progress. On September 5th, the Secretary General visited Skopje to discuss Macedonia's path forward;  “'NATO’s door is open, but only the people of this country can decide to walk through it. So your future is in your hands.' He underlined that there would be 'no way' for the country to join NATO without implementing the name agreement, calling it a 'once-in-a-lifetime' opportunity." Recently, Macedonia held the referendum to vote on the name change. Even though there was a low voter turn-out, the country has decided to approve of the name change. Prime Minister Zaev declared, "The people made a great choice and said ‘yes’ to our future. It is time for lawmakers to follow the voice of the people and to provide support. There will be no better agreement with Greece, nor an alternative for NATO and the EU.” On October 2nd, the Secretary General gave a brief following the referendum in Macedonia. He state, "Accession talks have already begun. And I expect that we will conclude them by January next year. Once all the constitutional changes on the new name are completed we can sign the accession protocol. Giving Skopje a seat at NATO’s table early next year." That being said, unless a major change regarding the referendum and name change occurs, Macedonia will be on schedule to join NATO by next year. https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/news_157861.htm?selectedLocale=en
http://time.com/5411191/macedonia-referendum-nato-name-change/
https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/opinions_158684.htm?selectedLocale=ru

For purposes question, it seems resolved, name change doesn’t have to happen if accession process has been made, right?
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/778523. Thanks to @dsarin

Invitation letter to join in July. And now the confirmation that the accession talks (Step 1 in Accession Process) have begun: https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/news_157861.htm?selectedLocale=en
"Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg wrapped up a two-day visit to Skopje on Thursday (6 September 2018), which focused on the country’s path toward NATO membership. At the Brussels Summit in July, Allied leaders decided to invite the government in Skopje to begin accession talks with the Alliance, which have now begun."  The question is resolved for at least one country. Yes, the change of the name should be added to the constitution, the condition for accession to NATO. But it looks, NATO went ahead anyway. Without the name change, if it fails in the Parliament, they may not proceed to the next stage. But formally the "progress" already happened. Will another country see progress? Maybe in the future, but unlikely till the deadline.

Classification: NATO UNCLASSIFIED
Hi Dsarin, Accession talks have begun. NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg said this on 2 October: Jens Stoltenberg [NATO Secretary General]: “The accession talks continue … the accession talks with the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia continues, as long as your country wants to continue those talks and as long as you are implementing the name agreement.  And we stand ready to welcome your country as a new member of the Alliance, with an equal seat around the NATO table, with full membership and also with all the benefits that NATO membership will provide to the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.  Because we have seen before that NATO membership is important for security, for stability, but also for prosperity.  The latest example is Montenegro, where investments have doubled since they joined NATO.  It's for Skopje to decide the way forward now.  It was a clear majority in favour of the name agreement, in favour of joining EU and NATO, in the referendum.  But at the same time, the turnout was not as high as many had hoped.  This is a consultative referendum, and the necessary changes in the constitution have to be made by the parliament.  Again, that’s for the parliament and for the people of the country to decide.  What I can say is that the only way to join NATO is by agreeing and implementing the name deal with Greece.  There is no other way.  So, I have seen that someone has indicated the possibility of rejecting the name agreement and, at the same time, join NATO.  That will not happen.  That alternative doesn’t exist.  So, it's for the people of the country and the parliament in Skopje to decide.  But it's my obligation to make it absolutely clear that there is no way to join NATO without fully implementing the name deal.  We are ready to welcome you, but then, of course, you have to implement the deal.” Best regards,
Dylan  Dylan P. WHITE
Press Officer / Editor
NATO Press & Media  
Boulevard Leopold III, 1110 Brussels, Belgium
North Atlantic Treaty Organisation
Twitter: @DylanPWhite @Raahul_Kumar @Anneinak @Emil @Chrisp

Bucharest Summit Declaration 2008 
"We recognise the hard work and the commitment demonstrated by the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia1 to NATO values and Alliance operations. We commend them for their efforts to build a multi-ethnic society. Within the framework of the UN, many actors have worked hard to resolve the name issue, but the Alliance has noted with regret that these talks have not produced a successful outcome. Therefore we agreed that an invitation to the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia will be extended as soon as a mutually acceptable solution to the name issue has been reached. We encourage the negotiations to be resumed without delay and expect them to be concluded as soon as possible." https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/topics_48830.htm
"At the April 2008 Bucharest Summit, Allies agreed that an invitation to join the Alliance will be extended to the country as soon as a mutually acceptable solution to the issue over its name has been reached with Greece. This agreement has been consistently reiterated at subsequent Summits. At the July 2018 Brussels Summit, Allied leaders welcomed the historic agreement between Athens and Skopje on the solution of the name issue. In line with their policy, they decided to invite the government in Skopje to begin accession talks to join the Alliance. Full implementation of all prescribed internal procedures with respect to the agreement on the solution of the name issue is a condition for a successful conclusion of the accession process."

Macedonia, is the most likely candidate to advance in the process. Greece has been blocking it for years from joining the Alliance, primarily due to the naming dispute. However, there is political will in Athens and Skopje to overcome this dispute, however, recently the referendum failed in Skopje, which bodes awfully for Macedonia's NATO accession. Given recent developments in Eastern Europe such as Georgia's revolution and Macedonia's referendum, there are only two possible countries that might join NATO before April 2019. However, the internal politics of the aforementioned states are not likely to let the governments make a commitment to NATO their priorities in the nearest future.
When it comes to Georgia, the new government is currently preoccupied with eradicating corruption and their domestic situation as a whole. Making international commitments as big as joining NATO are not likely to be in the cards for Georgia for at least another year. However, once the internal overhaul is over, Georgia is likely to be the next country of the Eastern block to join NATO.
Given Macedonia's recent referendum vote on the name change of the state and a very low turn out, it is obvious that Macedonia is likely to be preoccupied with internal challenges for the nearest future. In particular, the challenge is to accommodate for the needs and repair relations between the majority population and Serb minorities. Thus, the internal struggles will slow down Macedonia's commitment to NATO.

In terms of timeline, he said that, according to the information NATO has received from Skopje, a referendum will be held in autumn, paving the way for a change to the constitution, and they hope to achieve this by mid-December, allowing the accession protocol to be signed in January 2019. After the accession protocol is signed, it is sent to all 29 member states, who will need to ratify it according to their national procedures. The official said that the country NATO will be watching very closely is Greece, stating that the agreement says that once Skopje has changed the constitution, Athens will ratify the name agreement and the accession protocol simultaneously. Ratification in member states typically takes a year, meaning that the full process of accession will probably be concluded by the end of 2020.

As I understand it, the MAP is NOT one of the 7 formal steps listed in NATO accession process: 1. Accession talks with a NATO team
2. Invitees send letters of intent to NATO, along with timetables for completion of reforms
3. Accession protocols are signed by NATO countries
4. Accession protocols are ratified by NATO countries
5. The Secretary General invites the potential new members to accede to the North Atlantic Treaty
6. Invitees accede to the North Atlantic Treaty in accordance with their national procedures
7. Upon depositing their instruments of accession with the US State Department, invitees formally become NATO members
(https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/topics_49212.htm#) Although NATO held a summit to formally announce the beginning of the accession talks for Macedonia (https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/news_157315.htm), they clearly stated that the talks would only continue (really, start excepting this announcement) once the name deal and all associated changes had been carried out.  So this seems to be at least in part a public relations announcement rather than the actual start of the 2 major meetings for politics/defense and resources/security/laws.  And I would guess it was made at least in part to strongly encourage Greece and Macedonia to make good on their recent agreement to the name change deal.  And that really is significant given that it is the first reasonably successful agreement to resolve the name dispute since 1991 when Macedonia broke away from Yugoslavia, and which Greece has used to block Macedonia's formal advance in the membership process in 2008.  But I'm not sure whether it counts as formal progress since it is still contingent upon the legal resolution of the name deal in 2 countries where opposition is still significant.
https://www.newsadvance.com/news/world/wire/bigger-is-better-nato-opens-up-to-macedonia-as-rifts/article_7d2b8a60-0d4e-534e-a2a0-dee295dd37ed.html
https://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/europe/progress-on-macedonia-name-change-highlights-balkan-divisions-1.3521780 And there seems to be some disagreement about whether Greece or Macedonia will be able to fulfill all of the legal terms of their recent agreement to go with "North Macedonia."  For one thing, Macedonia still has to formally changes it's country's constitution and hold a referendum on this.  The deal they recently signed with Greece got only 69 of the 120 deputies' votes in their Parliament, and the opposition party nationalists are staging protests and saying they will continue to oppose the process leading up to the referendum in October/November.  The President already refused to sign the deal last month and may try again to refuse to sign, though Macedonian law seems to allow for a law to be ratified despite this veto if it can be ratified twice in Parliament, which is has (and the Speaker of Parliament said he would send it through without signature, so there seems to be some likelihood that the President will again refuse to sign it).  There is wide national support in Macedonia to join Nato, so although people REALLY protested against in earlier this spring, a recent poll suggests that 50% of people are willing to accept the name change in order to join NATO (which doesn't seem like the most promising of starts)
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-greece-macedonia/macedonias-parliament-endorses-name-deal-with-greece-for-second-time-idUSKBN1JV1MP
https://www.rferl.org/a/macedonian-parliament-oks-name-deal-with-greece-for-second-time/29344830.html
http://eu.greekreporter.com/2018/02/03/majority-in-fyrom-support-deal-with-greece-on-name-poll/ And Greece isn't in a significantly better position.  For one thing, Greece's Parliament won't even vote to complete the name change recognition until Macedonia has changed their constitution.  Right now, a vote in Greece doesn't seem to be expected until early 2019.  And Greece's majority party, the radical left Syriza party, has only a slim majority in Parliament right now (even slimmer than the 69 / 120 in Macedonia) with 152 of 300.    
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-greece-macedonia-namechange/greek-minister-optimistic-over-macedonia-name-deal-despite-hurdles-idUSKBN1JO1HI While this is happening, there are protests on a not insignificant order over the deal that seems to have a slim majority in each of the countries' current governments.  In Greece protests have been going on since early this year, supported and paid for by a variety of organizations including churches, cultural groups, retired officers, etc., and polls suggest that a significant majority (around 70%) of Greeks oppose any agreement to the name.  In addition, Russia, who is very unhappy about another neighbor joining NATO sent it's own money and people in to help stir up local dissent to the deal, resulting in the Greek Parliament expelling some Russian diplomats.  The main opposition parties have vowed to oppose the vote and campaign against it, and even members of Tsirpas party have spoken out against the name deal.  Now Russia is claiming the US is behind Greece's action and vows it will reciprocate (which provides a cover for any who choose to believe it and allows for angry Greeks to stay angry).  The awkwardness for Greek patriots over the "name giveaway" that the "anti-nationalist" leader Tsirpas and his Syriza party have done is apparently also threatened by rumors and pressure from Albania to change its borders with Greece in its favor.

https://worldview.stratfor.com/article/macedonia-greece-russia-wades-fray-over-balkan-name-dispute
  So here's the situation as it seems to me now:
- Macedonia wanted to take the opportunity to move forward but NATO refused to make that happen unless they could get a deal on the name change, so Macedonia pushed it through the acceptance process as quickly as possible with a narrow margin, and enough opposition that it's not yet clear that the general popular vote will follow through in the Fall.
- NATO saw an opportunity to show that it will hold good on it's promises and welcome new members in if they make good on their promises for reform (unlike the EU, apparently, whose members want more proof of completed reforms here and elsewhere) and to show their support for the deal rather than let the fragile agreement easily fall apart as the countries continued to fight
- Macedonia has to change its constitution as well as get a general referendum of popular support to show that this will actually happen
- Assuming this happens (seem more likely than not - 70-90% chance?) then Greece has to agree to it (thankfully only in Parliament and not in a popular vote, where they would surely fail since Greeks have remarkably little practical benefits to lose in this fight and a lot of pride and cultural capital to maintain or even gain by their opposition).  Once Macedonia votes, Greece's Parliament will have to hold a vote to ratify the name deal, which is expected to take place next year.  However, next fall (early to mid-October 2019), and while the current party wishes to encourage the name deal, they have an extremely narrow majority (152 of 300; that said, their majority hasn't been much larger than that since their majority in 2015) and they could lose support from some supporting members of Parliament if national criticism increases or something happens to divide party members or supporters.  The likelihood of Greece's Parliament passing this next year are not clear yet, partly because of the distance in time and partly because public and political discussions may not show all the relevant issues and depth of divisions until they actually have to vote, which they don't yet have to do.  But I would say it's much lower than the likelihood of Macedonian approval - 40-60% chance? so if the question hasn't been resolved by the recent public announcement at the NATO summit that accession talks are starting for Macedonia, then I suspect that we may not have a much clearer idea of whether the accession talks will actually "start" until October/November when Macedonia holds its referendum and then Jan-Mar if/when Greece's Parliament votes to accept Macedonia's name change. On the other hand, I've lost out on the semantics of what IS is before, so you never know.  Maybe NATO's announcement on the 12th will count as formal progression even without the completion of the conditions.

Progression in the NATO accession process is similar to the minor leagues in baseball.  Having a chance to join NATO is a big deal.  The accession process is slow and moving up in status towards membership requires the subject country to meet criteria proposed by every NATO country and general guidelines.  Strategically and politically, Bosnia and Herzegovina is the logical choice.  The remaining countries currently in the accession process are Macedonia, Georgia and the Ukraine.  Each of the former nations do not meet portions of the general criteria or have disputes with current NATO members.  Furthermore, moving Bosnia and Herzegovina up the ladder would create a stronger Western block on the map and move a Slavic country closer to committing to the West.  Some constituencies of the country oppose NATO membership, but they are a minority and guaranteed Western aid in perpetuity is hard to turn down.

The bar to clear this questions is actually not very high given that there are so many ways for a country to "progress" including the Intensified Dialogue. Macedonia might be invited at the 11-12 July summit with Stoltenberg saying he "expects and hopes that NATO leaders at the summit will decide to start accession talks" [1] Even if they are not, they probably will by April 2019 given that many NATO members have long wanted this, Macedonia has reached an agreement on the name dispute with Greece (though ratification is uncertain) and Macedonia would be a safe way to expand the sphere of influence relative to Ukraine or Georgia. Sweden is another real possibility. Stoltenberg again: "“If Sweden were to apply to join, I think there would be broad support for that within NATO,” [2]. All four opposition parties are pushing for it amid growing Russian threat (perceived or real) and public support as per polling is growing [same source]. However, the minority center-left coalition is strongly against. The September election and the debate around it would be an important data point.  Finland seems like a more distant possibility with low public support though "many politicians in the current center-right government favor it." [3] [1] https://www.rferl.org/a/nato-chief-hopeful-macedonia-membership-talks-/29318441.html
[2] https://www.politico.eu/article/under-threat-sweden-rediscovers-its-viking-spirit-nato-russia/
[3] https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2018/06/28/world/europe/ap-eu-finland-russia-us-summit.html

As per NATO, "four partner countries have declared their aspirations to NATO membership: Bosnia and Herzegovina, Georgia, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and Ukraine." "The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has been assured that it will be invited to become a member as soon as a mutually acceptable solution to the issue over the country’s name has been reached with Greece.
Bosnia and Herzegovina was invited to join the Membership Action Plan (MAP) in April 2010 but its participation is pending the resolution of a key issue concerning immovable defence property.
At the 2008 Bucharest Summit, the Allies agreed that Georgia and Ukraine will become members of NATO in future."  The latest nation to join, Montenegro, took about 1 1/2 after "ascension talks" were extended.  It was announced this week that Colombia was invited to join as a "global partner" first country in Latin America to join but doesn't seem like this fits the ascension description.   The Bosnia Herzegovina issue seems to be stalled for the time being. Macedonia has the greatest chance and the agreement on the name change is advancing this week.
Littl eprogress and there is not interest to go in tht direction the oppostion is strong enough to get this paralized with multiple excuses.....

The name of Macedonia has been a source of contention between the two countries for decades, frustrating hopes of the tiny but strategically placed Balkan state of joining NATO, and the European Union, where Greece has veto rights. “I believe we have covered a great part of the distance, but we have more to cover,” Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras told journalists. He said progress had been substantive but that negotiations were complex and ‘multi-layered’. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-macedonia-greece-name/greece-and-macedonia-inch-closer-to-name-accord-but-not-quite-there-yet-idUSKCN1II1OF

There is an increasing possibility that the FYROM/Greece name dispute could reach a resolution this summer. Expect NATO progress would follow reasonably swiftly if a deal is struck. Still a way to go but a lot of the chatter underlying the news is that progress is very real https://www.reuters.com/article/us-macedonia-greece-name/macedonian-pm-sees-solution-to-name-dispute-with-greece-in-june-idUSKCN1II1OF

Of the four countries NATO has recognized with membership ambitions, Ukraine is too much of a mess, Bosnia and Herzegovina has internal political disagreements, Macedonia has the name dispute,  and Georgia seems very quiet (I can't find anything recent of the subject). While its possible Macedonia could resolve the name dispute and start the accession process or Sweden could start the process, stasis always seems more likely.

In an increasingly dangerous Europe, NATO is looking to expand the alliance, especially in the Balkans, right in the back yard in an increasingly aggressive Russia. Macedonia, a MAP (Member Accession Action Plan) member since 1999, would be an increasingly valuable 'base' for NATO in the Balkans. The recent recognition of Macedonia by Turkey in a decisive step toward accession, but Greece's refusal to recognize the country is a major drawback. Additionally, recent Democratic Backsliding in Bosnia has been a dissuading factor in its case for accession to NATO membership, but NATO's desperate need for a foothold in the Balkans could lead to its timely accession.

Athens considers plans for July 2018 Macedonia/FYROM NATO accession unworkable
https://www.neweurope.eu/article/athens-considers-plans-july-2018-macedoniafyrom-nato-accession-unworkable/

The most obvious candidate is Macedonia, whose government is pushing extremely hard on this. The name issue is closer than perhaps it has ever been, but Greek parliament is a tough sell, plus Russia has allies in Athens ( Russia assumed to be willing to go to significant lengths - see Montenegro plot Oct. 2016). Think Greece could come under pressure. Recent progress: https://www.ft.com/content/aac1f298-1bd5-11e8-aaca-4574d7dabfb6 - Greeks say resolution close (Feb 18)
https://www.neweurope.eu/article/athens-considers-plans-july-2018-macedoniafyrom-nato-accession-unworkable/ - Greeks say resolution by July not doable (Apr 18) Upshot: who knows?! Note that even second article there is a suggestion of progress by fall if not July. Do think if progress doesn't happen this year next year will be harder with Greek elections in October 2019. Skopje will keep trying either way (for now).  Sweden is another possible candidate but don't think will move until after GE in September 18 - opposition parties support membership, expect it to feature in autumn campaigns. NATO would like it...  Stoltenberg a fan! 
Finland unlikely to move this parliament (next election May 2019) : https://www.reuters.com/article/us-finland-nato-financeminister/joining-nato-would-help-finlands-security-but-unlikely-for-now-finance-minister-idUSKBN1DT2ON

So pretty tough picture. Don't think there will be actual expansion by next year necessarily, but still impressed by the bravery of the 100% on zero brigade.
